abstract: Think how the jack-of-all-trades mobile phones pushed aside the dedicated personal digital organizers.
snippet: Think how the jack-of-all-trades mobile phones pushed aside the dedicated personal digital organizers.
lead_paragraph: The electronic book market is looking increasingly hot, flat and crowded. A vicious price war has broken out among producers of digital readers because of Apple’s success with the iPad. Companies like Amazon hope that selling tomes across multiple devices will fill the profit gap. But competition in e-book distribution is heating up and could pressure margins there, too.

headline.main: Will the iPad Undercut Digital Readers?
headline.print_headline: The iPad Factor In Digital Readers

abstract: In the race to bring music collections from the PC up to the cloud, mSpot, eMusic and Thumbplay Music are three companies to watch.
snippet: In the race to bring music collections from the PC up to the cloud, mSpot, eMusic and Thumbplay Music are three companies to watch.
lead_paragraph: Internet observers eagerly awaiting the arrival of “music in the cloud”— services that store people’s music collections on the Web and stream their songs to any computer or mobile device — tend to focus their attention on the plans of the big guys like Apple, Google and Amazon and the brand-name subscription services like Rhapsody and Spotify.

headline.main: Three Cloud Music Companies to Watch

abstract: Apple said the release of the iPhone 4 was its most successful product introduction yet.
snippet: Apple said the release of the iPhone 4 was its most successful product introduction yet.
lead_paragraph: Apple said it sold more than 1.7 million units of the iPhone 4 over the first weekend it was available for purchase.

headline.main: Apple Sells 1.7 Million New iPhones in Three Days

byline.original: By Jenna Wortham and Nick Bilton

abstract: Like Google and Facebook, Apple has been confronted with Germany’s privacy laws, among Europe’s stiffest.
snippet: Like Google and Facebook, Apple has been confronted with Germany’s privacy laws, among Europe’s stiffest.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN  The justice minister of Germany expressed concern on Monday over Apple’s practice of compiling data on users of its new iPhone, making the company the latest technology giant to fall afoul of the country’s strict privacy laws.

headline.main: Germany Asks Apple About iPhone’s Data-Gathering
headline.print_headline: Germany Asks Apple About iPhone’s Data-Gathering
